articles.headline: Inside Saudi Arabia’s Global Push for Nuclear Power
articles.snippet: Despite qualms in Washington, Saudi officials have pressed the United States to help them develop nuclear power. But they are also exploring other options, including China.
articles.abstract: Despite qualms in Washington, Saudi officials have pressed the United States to help them develop nuclear power. But they are also exploring other options, including China.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Saudi Arabia has pressed the United States to help it develop a nuclear energy program, as Saudi leaders look beyond oil to power their country.
articles.byline: By Edward Wong, Vivian Nereim and Kate Kelly

articles.headline: China Draws Lessons From Russia’s Losses in Ukraine, and Its Gains
articles.snippet: With an eye on a possible conflict over Taiwan, analysts have scrutinized the war for insights ranging from the importance of supply lines to the power of nuclear threats.
articles.abstract: With an eye on a possible conflict over Taiwan, analysts have scrutinized the war for insights ranging from the importance of supply lines to the power of nuclear threats.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thousands of miles from the cities that Russia is bombing in Ukraine, China has been studying the war.

articles.headline: Venice Is Saved! Woe Is Venice.
articles.snippet: Produced by Mona Boshnaq
articles.abstract: Produced by Mona Boshnaq
articles.lead_paragraph: In the middle of the night, as the tide rose, winds whipped and waves grew, an engineer in a command center on an artificial island on the rim of the Venice lagoon clicked an arrow on his screen reading, “Lift.”
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz, Emma Bubola and Laetitia Vancon

articles.headline: A Chicago Mayoral Hopeful Who Took on Hard-to-Fix Schools Faces a Political Shift
articles.snippet: Paul Vallas has long been a supporter of charter schools. He is running against Brandon Johnson, an ex-teacher with a different approach.
articles.abstract: Paul Vallas has long been a supporter of charter schools. He is running against Brandon Johnson, an ex-teacher with a different approach.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of the 2023 Chicago mayoral runoff election.
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: The Children’s Rights Advocate Accused of Russian War Crimes
articles.snippet: Maria Lvova-Belova says she is running a humanitarian evacuation of abandoned Ukrainian children. The International Criminal Court accuses her of abducting them wholesale.
articles.abstract: Maria Lvova-Belova says she is running a humanitarian evacuation of abandoned Ukrainian children. The International Criminal Court accuses her of abducting them wholesale.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — As children gathered at a holiday camp outside Moscow, they were greeted by a female performer in a kokoshnik, a traditional tiara, who extended the customary Russian greeting of a loaf of bread and salt.

articles.headline: SPAC Tied to Trump Media Rushes to Complete Deal
articles.snippet: The merger of Digital World and Trump Media has been held up by investigations, but executives are rushing to complete the deal by a Sept. 8 deadline.
articles.abstract: The merger of Digital World and Trump Media has been held up by investigations, but executives are rushing to complete the deal by a Sept. 8 deadline.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly 18 months ago, an obscure investment banker unveiled a blockbuster deal: His so-called blank-check company would bankroll a social media outfit that former President Donald J. Trump planned to start with hundreds of millions of dollars.

articles.headline: Norfolk Southern’s Push for Profits Compromised Safety, Workers Say
articles.snippet: Federal officials are investigating the railroad’s safety practices and culture after the derailment in East Palestine, Ohio, and worker deaths.
articles.abstract: Federal officials are investigating the railroad’s safety practices and culture after the derailment in East Palestine, Ohio, and worker deaths.
articles.lead_paragraph: Norfolk Southern once had so few accidents and injuries that it won the rail industry’s prestigious E.H. Harriman safety award for 23 years in a row until it was retired in 2012. But in the last decade, the company has gone from an industry leader to a laggard.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis, Mark Walker and Niraj Chokshi

articles.headline: Democrats Run on Abortion, Even for Offices With Little Say on the Issue
articles.snippet: Seizing on a powerful motivator for their party, Democratic candidates for municipal offices have put Republicans on their heels. “I’m running for mayor, I’m not debating abortion,” one said.
articles.abstract: Seizing on a powerful motivator for their party, Democratic candidates for municipal offices have put Republicans on their heels. “I’m running for mayor, I’m not debating abortion,” one said.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — Eric Genrich is running a full-throated campaign in support of abortion rights, reminding voters of his position at every turn and hammering his anti-abortion opponent in television ads. At a recent event, he featured an obstetrician who now commutes to a state where abortion is legal to treat patients and a local woman who traveled to Colorado to terminate a nonviable pregnancy.

articles.headline: Trump Flourishes in the Glare of His Indictment
articles.snippet: The former president’s appetite for attention has been fundamental to his identity for decades. Where others may focus on the hazards of a criminal case, he raises money, promotes his campaign and works to reduce the case to a cliffhanging spectac...
articles.abstract: The former president’s appetite for attention has been fundamental to his identity for decades. Where others may focus on the hazards of a criminal case, he raises money, promotes his campaign and works to reduce the case to a cliffhanging spectacle.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since long before he entered the White House, former President Donald J. Trump has been an any-publicity-is-good-publicity kind of guy. In fact, he once told advisers, “There’s no bad press unless you’re a pedophile.” Hush money for a porn star? Evidently not an exception to that rule.

articles.headline: A Front Company and a Fake Identity: How the U.S. Came to Use Spyware It Was Trying to Kill.
articles.snippet: The Biden administration has been trying to choke off use of hacking tools made by the Israeli firm NSO. It turns out that not every part of the government has gotten the message.
articles.abstract: The Biden administration has been trying to choke off use of hacking tools made by the Israeli firm NSO. It turns out that not every part of the government has gotten the message.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The secret contract was finalized on Nov. 8, 2021, a deal between a company that has acted as a front for the United States government and the American affiliate of a notorious Israeli hacking firm.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: Tulare Lake Was Drained Off the Map. Nature Would Like a Word.
articles.snippet: A barrage of storms has resurrected what was once the largest body of fresh water west of the Mississippi River, setting the stage for a disaster this spring.
articles.abstract: A barrage of storms has resurrected what was once the largest body of fresh water west of the Mississippi River, setting the stage for a disaster this spring.
articles.lead_paragraph: CORCORAN, Calif. — It is no secret to locals that the heart of California’s Central Valley was once the largest body of fresh water west of the Mississippi River, dammed and drained into an empire of farms by the mid-20th century.
articles.byline: By Soumya Karlamangla and Shawn Hubler

articles.headline: Donald Trump and New York City Brace for a Consequential Week
articles.snippet: As the former president traveled to Manhattan for his arrest on Tuesday, his team weighed how to capitalize on it, while officials in New York prepared for potential turmoil.
articles.abstract: As the former president traveled to Manhattan for his arrest on Tuesday, his team weighed how to capitalize on it, while officials in New York prepared for potential turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump made his heavily anticipated arrival in New York on Monday as he prepared to walk into a Manhattan courtroom as both a defendant and a candidate.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Jonathan Swan

articles.headline: Noncompete Clauses Get Tighter, and TV Newsrooms Feel the Grip
articles.snippet: Job-switching barriers are routine at TV stations, even for workers not on the air. A proposed federal rule would curb the practice across all fields.
articles.abstract: Job-switching barriers are routine at TV stations, even for workers not on the air. A proposed federal rule would curb the practice across all fields.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of all the professions, perhaps none is more commonly bound by contracts that define where else an employee can go work than local television news.

articles.headline: Netflix’s Approach Shifts, Pushing Content That Can ‘Pop’
articles.snippet: The streaming service long thought spending on ads didn’t result in more viewers. That has subtly changed under the marketing chief Marian Lee.
articles.abstract: The streaming service long thought spending on ads didn’t result in more viewers. That has subtly changed under the marketing chief Marian Lee.
articles.lead_paragraph: Netflix made sure viewers had ample opportunity to hear about “Wednesday,” its macabre hit starring Jenna Ortega.

articles.headline: How the U.S., Family and Hollywood Freed the ‘Hotel Rwanda’ Hero
articles.snippet: Paul Rusesabagina, depicted in the 2004 film about genocide in his country, was reunited with his family last week. It took years of pressure to get him out of Rwanda, where he was convicted on terrorism charges.
articles.abstract: Paul Rusesabagina, depicted in the 2004 film about genocide in his country, was reunited with his family last week. It took years of pressure to get him out of Rwanda, where he was convicted on terrorism charges.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rwanda’s leader was in combative form last December when, on a visit to Washington, he was asked about his country’s most famous political prisoner, and his personal foe.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh, Michael D. Shear and Abdi Latif Dahir

articles.headline: New Weapons Aren’t Enough: The Challenges of Ukraine’s Coming Assault
articles.snippet: With powerful Western weapons, newly formed assault units and even a reconstituted Azov battalion, Ukraine is poised for a critical spring counteroffensive. But overcoming casualties and keeping war-weary troops motivated will be stern tests.
articles.abstract: With powerful Western weapons, newly formed assault units and even a reconstituted Azov battalion, Ukraine is poised for a critical spring counteroffensive. But overcoming casualties and keeping war-weary troops motivated will be stern tests.
articles.lead_paragraph: In vicious but mostly static fighting in snowy, artillery-cratered fields and ruined cities, Ukraine rebuffed a Russian offensive over the winter. Now, it is Ukraine’s turn to go on the attack.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Mauricio Lima

articles.headline: Oil Prices Jump, as OPEC Production Cut Draws U.S. Concern
articles.snippet: A Saudi-led move to reduce output among major oil producers pushed prices higher. The White House said it didn’t think the cuts were warranted.
articles.abstract: A Saudi-led move to reduce output among major oil producers pushed prices higher. The White House said it didn’t think the cuts were warranted.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oil prices surged on Monday and U.S. officials voiced their displeasure a day after OPEC members announced substantial cuts in production, a move that reaffirmed Saudi Arabia, the group’s leader, as a headstrong giant in the oil market.

articles.headline: Endeavor and W.W.E. Join Forces to Create Live-Combat Tag Team
articles.snippet: The new company, with the stock ticker “TKO,” is betting that the value of rights for live events like wrestling will continue to soar.
articles.abstract: The new company, with the stock ticker “TKO,” is betting that the value of rights for live events like wrestling will continue to soar.
articles.lead_paragraph: The tens of thousands of fans who crowded into SoFi Stadium in Los Angeles for WrestleMania this weekend got to watch the wrestling icon John Cena be hurled to the canvas by Austin Theory, one of World Wrestling Entertainment’s biggest stars.

articles.headline: Biden’s Reluctant Approach to Free Trade Draws Backlash
articles.snippet: A law intended to bolster clean energy manufacturing has ignited debate over whether the U.S. should work to break down international trade barriers — or keep them intact to protect American workers.
articles.abstract: A law intended to bolster clean energy manufacturing has ignited debate over whether the U.S. should work to break down international trade barriers — or keep them intact to protect American workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Since President Biden came into office two years ago, the United States has declined to pursue new comprehensive free-trade agreements with other countries, arguing that most Americans have turned against the kind of pacts that promote global commerce but that also help to send factory jobs overseas.

articles.headline: Death and Justice on the Border: A Migrant Is Killed, a Rancher Is Charged
articles.snippet: An unarmed Mexican man was shot as he crossed an Arizona ranch. The case against the ranch owner has prompted a backlash among supporters who say he is the real victim.
articles.abstract: An unarmed Mexican man was shot as he crossed an Arizona ranch. The case against the ranch owner has prompted a backlash among supporters who say he is the real victim.
articles.lead_paragraph: KINO SPRINGS, Ariz. — Gabriel Cuen-Buitimea was slipping across a rancher’s land near the border with Mexico when the shooting started. “I’m hit,” he said, before his eyes rolled back and he crumpled face down by a mesquite tree.
